marketSizing.fullContent:
# AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ ‚Ä¢ Market Sizing

Below I estimate the Total Addressable Market (TAM) for AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢‚Äôs primary market (AI upskilling & transformation for marketing/product teams in medium‚Üílarge enterprises) using both Top‚ÄëDown and Bottom‚ÄëUp methods. I show formulas, explicit assumptions (with reasoning / best‚Äëguess sources), produce TAM / SAM / SOM, include a sensitivity analysis (¬±20% on key assumptions), and finish with three concise go‚Äëto‚Äëmarket implications.

Summary (quick view)
- Top‚ÄëDown TAM (base case): ‚âà ¬£1.0B (range ¬£0.52B ‚Äì ¬£1.74B)
- Bottom‚ÄëUp TAM (base case): ‚âà ¬£4.0B (range ¬£2.56B ‚Äì ¬£5.76B)
- Reconciled/Recommended TAM (midpoint of the methods): ‚âà ¬£2.5B
- Recommended SAM (Brilliant Noise‚Äôs serviceable market given focus on global brands & premium positioning): ‚âà ¬£750M (30% of TAM)
- Recommended SOM (near-term / 12‚Äì24 months achievable): ‚âà ¬£11‚Äì15M (‚âà1.5‚Äì2% of SAM). 3‚Äëyear target SOM: ‚âà ¬£45M (‚âà6% of SAM).

I. Definitions & approach
- TAM = total revenue opportunity for AI upskilling & transformation services for marketing/product teams in enterprises (global).
- SAM = portion of TAM addressable given Brilliant Noise‚Äôs positioning (global brands, B‚ÄëCorp, Brighton-based boutique, premium price).
- SOM = realistic market share Brilliant Noise can capture in near term (12‚Äì24 months) given current scale; and a 3‚Äëyear aspirational figure.

II. Top‚ÄëDown approach
Formula (Top‚ÄëDown):
TAM_TD = Global_Corporate_L&D_Spend √ó Share_50+_firms √ó Share_for_marketing/product_teams √ó Share_of_L&D_allocated_to_AI_upskilling

Assumptions & reasoning (each explicitly stated)
1. Global corporate L&D market (2023/24) ‚âà $360B ‚Üí convert at $1.25/¬£1 ‚Üí ¬£288B.
   - Rationale: industry reports (various market research summaries of corporate training / L&D / e‚Äëlearning) cluster in the low hundreds of billions; I use a conservative midpoint of $360B (callout: estimates vary $300‚Äì$450B depending on definitions).
2. Share of L&D spend by enterprises with 50+ employees = 70% ‚Üí large firms drive most L&D budgets.
   - Rationale: small firms spend much less; mid/large firms (the ICP) consume the majority.
3. Share of that spend applied to marketing/product teams = 10%.
   - Rationale: L&D spans many functions; marketing/product are significant but not dominant.
4. Share of marketing/product L&D allocated specifically to AI / automation / advanced digital upskilling = 5%
   - Rationale: AI upskilling is a rising but still small portion of budgets today; 3‚Äì7% plausible near term.

Calculation (base):
TAM_TD = ¬£288B √ó 0.70 √ó 0.10 √ó 0.05 = ¬£1.008B

Top‚ÄëDown sensitivity (¬±20% applied to key % assumptions: 50+ share, marketing share, AI share)
- Worst case (‚àí20% on all): 288 √ó 0.56 √ó 0.08 √ó 0.04 = ¬£0.52B
- Best case (+20% on all): 288 √ó 0.84 √ó 0.12 √ó 0.06 = ¬£1.74B
=> Top‚ÄëDown range: ‚âà ¬£0.52B ‚Äì ¬£1.74B (base ‚âà ¬£1.01B)

III. Bottom‚ÄëUp approach
Formula (Bottom‚ÄëUp):
TAM_BU = Number_of_target_companies √ó Average_annual_revenue_per_customer (ARPA)

Assumptions & reasoning
1. Target company definition for AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢: enterprises with 150+ employees (ideal client profile: medium‚Üílarge, global brands). This product is also "perfect for 50+ employees" but marketing/product teams in 150+ firms are primary buyers.
2. Number of target companies globally (150+ employees): base = 160,000
   - Rationale / best‚Äëguess logic: rough aggregation of mid+large enterprises across developed markets (US, EU, UK, Australia, Canada, Japan) and large corporates globally. (This is an estimate; sensitivity analysis will show impact.)
3. Average annual revenue per customer (ARPA) = ¬£25,000
   - Rationale: pricing: Executive Briefing ¬£2k, Team Workshop ¬£8.8k, Complete Sprint ¬£17.5k. Typical client buys a Complete Sprint or workshop(s) and follow‚Äëon support; premium global brands may buy multiple sprints / enterprise packages ‚Üí average ¬£20k‚Äì¬£30k reasonable. I use ¬£25k as base.

Calculation (base):
TAM_BU = 160,000 √ó ¬£25,000 = ¬£4,000,000,000 = ¬£4.0B

Bottom‚ÄëUp sensitivity (¬±20% on two drivers)
- Companies: 128k ‚Üí 192k (‚àí20% / +20%)
- ARPA: ¬£20k ‚Üí ¬£30k (‚àí20% / +20%)
Compute extreme combos:
- Low‚Äëlow: 128k √ó ¬£20k = ¬£2.56B
- Base: 160k √ó ¬£25k = ¬£4.0B
- High‚Äëhigh: 192k √ó ¬£30k = ¬£5.76B
=> Bottom‚ÄëUp range: ‚âà ¬£2.56B ‚Äì ¬£5.76B

IV. Reconciling Top‚ÄëDown & Bottom‚ÄëUp ‚Üí Recommended TAM
- Top‚ÄëDown base ‚âà ¬£1.01B; Bottom‚ÄëUp base ‚âà ¬£4.0B. These are different because top‚Äëdown 1) uses a conservative share of AI budgets and 2) constrains to marketing team fraction of L&D.
- Recommended approach: present a reconciled TAM = midpoint of the two approaches (simple average) to reflect both market‚Äëlevel and customer‚Äëlevel perspectives: (1.01B + 4.0B) / 2 ‚âà ¬£2.5B.
- Reported TAM (recommended): ‚âà ¬£2.5B (range across methods ‚âà ¬£0.52B ‚Äì ¬£5.76B; a more realistic working range = ¬£1.0B‚Äì¬£5.8B).

V. SAM & SOM (with rationale)

  - SAM = 30% √ó ¬£2.5B = ¬£750M
  - Rationale: higher than a small boutique‚Äôs pure geography would imply because Brilliant Noise already works with global brands (adidas, BMW, Nestle). 30% reflects selective targeting of high‚Äëvalue customers rather than mass market.
- SOM (Serviceable Obtainable Market)
  - Near term (12‚Äì24 months, realistic given current capacity and sales velocity): capture ‚âà1.5‚Äì2.0% of SAM.
    - SOM_yr1‚Äì2 = 1.5% √ó ¬£750M = ¬£11.25M ‚Üí 2.0% √ó ¬£750M = ¬£15.0M
    - So near‚Äëterm SOM ‚âà ¬£11‚Äì15M (ARR / annual revenue)
  - 3‚Äëyear target (with investment in sales, partners, productization): 5‚Äì8% of SAM.
    - SOM_3yr = 6% √ó ¬£750M ‚âà ¬£45M (midpoint target)

VI. Sensitivity summary (key variables ¬±20%) ‚Äî condensed table style (numbers in ¬£)
- Top‚ÄëDown (AI share/marketing share/50+ share varying) ‚Üí TAM ‚âà ¬£0.52B ‚Äì ¬£1.74B
- Bottom‚ÄëUp (companies √ó ARPA varying) ‚Üí TAM ‚âà ¬£2.56B ‚Äì ¬£5.76B
- Combined/recommended TAM = ¬£2.5B (use with caution; plan for scenarios)

Practical numeric scenarios (rounded)
- Conservative TAM scenario (top‚Äëdown pessimistic): ~¬£0.6B
- Base TAM scenario (recommended midpoint): ~¬£2.5B
- Aggressive TAM scenario (bottom‚Äëup optimistic): ~¬£5.8B

VII. Key assumptions & sources / logic recap
- Global corporate L&D market: assumed $360B (industry reports vary; adjust if you prefer $300‚Äì$450B).
- Exchange rate: $1.25 = ¬£1 (use your actual FX for final planning).
- Target company counts: estimated 160k companies with 150+ staff globally (best‚Äëguess). If you have customer analytics or country firm counts, replace this with data‚Äëdriven counts.
- ARPA = ¬£25k/year assumed based on product price points and expected follow‚Äëon purchases.
- Share allocations (marketing share of L&D, AI share) are directional estimates reflecting market dynamics (AI being an accelerating but still minority share of total L&D spend today).

VIII. Three implications for go‚Äëto‚Äëmarket (concise, actionable)
1. Prioritise high‚ÄëARPA accounts (enterprise global brands) ‚Äî they drive most revenue:
   - Rationale: TAM math shows large enterprises unlock outsized revenue. Pursue a ‚Äúland big accounts‚Äù approach (target CMOs/CDOs at global brands), where a single Complete Sprint + follow‚Äëon support yields high lifetime value. Invest in account‚Äëbased marketing and case studies.

   - Rationale: to convert enterprise buyers faster and expand capacity, partner with HR/L&D platforms, learning marketplaces, and complementary consultancies; and lead with quantified ROI (hours saved √ó salary cost models) in sales collateral to shorten procurement cycles.

IX. How to tighten estimates (next steps / recommended data pulls)
- Replace the 160k target‚Äëcompany estimate with authoritative firm‚Äëcounts by employee band for target geographies (ONS / Eurostat / US Census / Orbis).
- Replace ARPA with CRM/historic win data (average sale per account, churn, upsell).

Step 5 ‚Äî Measurement & tracking (12s)

sections.AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ ‚Ä¢ Presentation Structure:
AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ ‚Äî Sales Presentation Playbook
Purpose: A repeatable, modular sales presentation structure your team can use for 30‚Äëminute pitches, 90‚Äëminute executive briefings and longer workshops. Includes a 10‚Äëslide core deck outline (headlines + key talking points), optional deep‚Äëdive modules (technical, ROI, implementation), audience customization guidance, and visual/demo insertion points. Each slide includes time allocations and transition phrases.

1) Core 10‚ÄëSlide Deck (compact + extendable)
Notes: Two timing schemas shown per slide ‚Äî Quick Pitch (30m total: ~20‚Äì25m presentation + 5‚Äì10m Q&A) and Executive Briefing (90m total: ~60‚Äì75m presentation + 15‚Äì30m interactive work/Q&A). Use the short times for cold calls / discovery meetings; use extended times during paid Executive Briefings.

Slide 1 ‚Äî Title & Hook
- Time: Quick 1 min / Exec 3 min
- Headline: AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ ‚Äî Turn your whole team into AI power users in 90 days
- Key talking points: One‚Äëline value prop (90% using AI weekly within 30 days; 20+ hours saved per person/month); who we are (Brilliant Noise, Brighton B‚ÄëCorp, clients like adidas/BMW/Nestl√©); what this session will cover.
- Visual/demo cue: Brand slide with 1‚Äëline animation of the 90‚Äëday journey.
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs why this matters for your team right now.‚Äù

Slide 2 ‚Äî Problem (Context & Pain)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 5 min
- Headline: Adoption stalls ‚Äî pilots, tool fragmentation and lack of role training
- Key talking points: Typical failure modes (pilot fatigue, tool overload, skills gap); business consequences (wasted time, lost agility, missed revenue/marketing performance).
- Audience question: ‚ÄúWhich of these sounds like your team?‚Äù
- Transition: ‚ÄúSo what does success look like? A practical route from talk to daily use.‚Äù

Slide 3 ‚Äî Solution Overview
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 6 min
- Headline: AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢: Test‚ÄëLearn‚ÄëLead‚Ñ¢ for practical AI adoption
- Key talking points: Program components (exec alignment, role‚Äëbased workshops, progress tracking); modular curriculum; outcome promise (90% active use, 20+ hours saved).
- Visual: 3‚Äëstep Test‚ÄëLearn‚ÄëLead‚Ñ¢ graphic.
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how the programme works in practice.‚Äù

Slide 4 ‚Äî How It Works (Methodology)
- Time: Quick 3 min / Exec 8 min
- Headline: Hands‚Äëon curriculum, role paths and real work scenarios
- Key talking points: Sprint structure (Executive Briefing, Team Workshop Day, Sprint Package); role‚Äëspecific learning paths; measurement framework and success metrics.
- Demo cue: Slide with sample week‚Äëby‚Äëweek timeline.
- Transition: ‚ÄúLet me show evidence this actually delivers.‚Äù

Slide 5 ‚Äî Evidence & Outcomes (Proof)
- Time: Quick 3 min / Exec 8 min
- Headline: Measurable gains ‚Äî case evidence and client outcomes
- Key talking points: Case snapshots (adidas/BMW/Nestl√©) with outcomes (hours saved, adoption %); testimonials/quote; metrics we track (usage, productivity hours saved, campaign lift).
- Visual/demo cue: Before/after metrics dashboard screenshot or short customer video (30‚Äì60s).
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what you get when you buy AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢.‚Äù

Slide 6 ‚Äî Deliverables & Pricing
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 5 min
- Headline: Offerings: Executive Briefing (¬£2k) ‚Ä¢ Team Workshop Day (¬£8.8k) ‚Ä¢ Complete Sprint (¬£17.5k)
- Key talking points: What each package contains, who it‚Äôs for, typical outcomes per package, expected timeline to first impact (30 days for weekly use).
- Transition: ‚ÄúNow let‚Äôs cover how this integrates with your systems and people.‚Äù

Slide 7 ‚Äî Integration & Security (High‚Äëlevel)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 6 min
- Headline: Practical integration ‚Äî tools, data & governance
- Key talking points: We‚Äôre not a systems integrator; we enable people to use existing tools safely (prompt frameworks, data handling rules); basic architecture/integration touchpoints; B‚ÄëCorp values and responsible AI practice.
- Demo cue: Architecture sketch + governance checklist.
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how we make adoption real in day‚Äëto‚Äëday work.‚Äù

Slide 8 ‚Äî Typical Implementation Path & Timeline
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 6 min
- Headline: From briefing to org‚Äëwide use ‚Äî a 90‚Äëday path
- Key talking points: Milestones (exec alignment, workshops, role pilots, measurement); success checkpoints; client responsibilities and Brilliant Noise support.
- Visual: 90‚Äëday roadmap with key deliverables.
- Transition: ‚ÄúFrequently asked question: what ROI can you expect?‚Äù

Slide 9 ‚Äî ROI & Business Case (brief)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 8 min
- Headline: Rapid productivity gains that show ROI fast
- Key talking points: Typical ROI math (hours saved per user √ó user count √ó value/hour); evidence from pilots; payback examples for 150+ employee organisations.
- Demo cue: Simple ROI calculator mockup (interactive if exec wants numbers).
- Transition: ‚ÄúCommon questions ‚Äî and quickly, why pick Brilliant Noise?‚Äù

Slide 10 ‚Äî Why Brilliant Noise & Next Steps (Close + CTA)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 5‚Äì8 min
- Headline: Brighton boutique, global pedigree ‚Äî commercial focus + ethics
- Key talking points: Differentiators (Test‚ÄëLearn‚ÄëLead‚Ñ¢, B‚ÄëCorp, leadership experience, client list); recommended next step (book Executive Briefing or complete Sprint); timeline for onboarding; logistics/pricing recap.
- CTA: Propose dates/options, ask for commitment to next step.
- Transition to Q&A: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love your questions ‚Äî and to tailor the next session to what matters most for you.‚Äù

2) Optional Deep‚ÄëDive Modules (plug into Slide 4‚Äì9 as needed)
Include module purpose, duration, when to use, contents, visuals and transition phrases.

A. Technical Deep‚ÄëDive (for CTOs/IT)
- Duration: 20‚Äì35 minutes (add to 90m session or separate 45m follow‚Äëup)
- Objective: Show architecture, integrations, security, vendor choices and scale considerations.
- Contents: integration options (SaaS tools, LLM access), data governance & PII handling, SSO/permissions, orchestration (prompt libraries + templates), scalability & change control.
- Visuals: system diagrams, data flow, security checklist, integration matrix.
- Trigger: Asked by technical stakeholders or when data access is complex.
- Transition phrase: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs step under the hood to show how this fits your stack and governance.‚Äù

B. ROI & Business Case Deep‚ÄëDive (for CFO/CMO)
- Duration: 20‚Äì30 minutes
- Objective: Build a tailored ROI model and payback scenario.
- Contents: Inputs needed (users, roles, current time spent on routine tasks, average value per hour), sensitivity analysis, case study math, risk/assumption list.
- Visuals: Interactive ROI calculator, scenario slides, payback timeline.
- Trigger: Execs asking about cost/benefit or procurement stakeholders.
- Transition phrase: ‚ÄúNow we‚Äôll translate adoption into hard numbers for your organisation.‚Äù

C. Implementation & Change Management Module (for HR/Operations/Change leads)
- Duration: 20‚Äì30 minutes
- Objective: Show people plan, learning paths, measurement and sustainment.
- Contents: Role‚Äëspecific curricula, workshop formats, coaching/certification, measurement dashboard, adoption playbook (champions, comms, incentives).
- Visuals: sample role learning path, adoption dashboard, comms plan calendar.
- Trigger: When customer cites culture/resistance or needs rollout planning.
- Transition phrase: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the sequence and people plan that turns training into habit.‚Äù

3) Customization Guide by Audience Type
Quick rules for tailoring language, slides to emphasize, suggested questions to ask, and KPIs to highlight.

A. Executives (CMO, CDO, C‚Äësuite)
- Tone: Outcomes, risk mitigation, speed to value, competitive advantage.
- Emphasize: Slide 1 hook, Slides 5 (evidence), 6 (pricing/options), 9 (ROI), 10 (why us).
- Swap in: ROI Deep‚ÄëDive; high‚Äëlevel security assurances.
- Questions to ask: ‚ÄúWhich KPIs matter most this quarter? What‚Äôs acceptable payback period?‚Äù 
- KPIs to highlight: time saved per user, adoption %, campaign performance lift, payback months.

B. Technical (CTO, Head of Data, Security)
- Tone: Precise, pragmatic, compliance‚Äëfocused.
- Emphasize: Slides 7 (integration/security), 4 (methodology), Technical Deep‚ÄëDive.
- Swap in: Longer technical appendix; vendor integration examples; SSO/permissions slides.
- Questions: ‚ÄúWhat governance frameworks do you use? Which systems must integrate?‚Äù
- KPIs: data risk mitigations, latency, uptime, integration effort estimates.

C. End‚Äëusers / Practitioners (Marketers, Product Owners)
- Tone: Hands‚Äëon, work‚Äësaving, demonstrative.
- Emphasize: Slides 3‚Äì5 (how it works, evidence), demo insertions, Implementation Module.
- Swap in: Role‚Äëspecific learning path examples and short live prompts/demo.
- Questions: ‚ÄúWhat repetitive tasks take most time? Who‚Äôs using which tools?‚Äù
- KPIs: time saved, workflows automated, number of daily tool actions reduced.

4) Visual & Demo Insertion Points (what to show and when)
- Slide 1 (Hook): Short animated 90‚Äëday journey graphic.
- Slide 3‚Äì4 (Method & How): Timeline/roadmap animation; visual of role paths.
- Slide 5 (Proof): Customer video clip (30‚Äì60s) or before/after metric cards.
- Slide 6 (Pricing): Package comparison table (interactive if shared screen).
- Slide 7 (Integration): Architecture diagram; live tour of a prompt library or template.
- Slide 8 (Timeline): Interactive 90‚Äëday planner (editable in session).
- Slide 9 (ROI): Live ROI calculator ‚Äî plug in the client‚Äôs numbers during briefing.
- During End‚Äëuser focus: Live demo of a prompt applied to a real task (copywriting, data summarisation, campaign brief creation) ‚Äî 3‚Äì5 minutes.
- Technical deep‚Äëdive: Live or recorded demo of sandbox integration, token management, or governance controls.
- Demo tech checks: Always test connectivity, video clips and any remote shares 10 minutes before session; have a screenshot backup.

5) Suggested Run Orders (ready‚Äëto‚Äëuse)
A. 30‚Äëminute Quick Pitch (ideal for discovery or initial outreach)
- 0:00‚Äì0:60s: Slide 1 (Hook) ‚Äî open & quick rapport
- 1:00‚Äì3:00: Slide 2 (Problem)
- 3:00‚Äì6:00: Slide 3 (Solution)
- 6:00‚Äì11:00: Slide 5 (Evidence) + quick visual
- 11:00‚Äì15:00: Slide 6 (Offer/Pricing)
- 15:00‚Äì18:00: Slide 9 (Quick ROI sketch)
- 18:00‚Äì23:00: Slide 10 (Why us & Next steps)
- 23:00‚Äì30:00: Q&A and agree next step (book Exec Briefing or Workshop)

B. 90‚Äëminute Executive Briefing (paid)
- 0:00‚Äì03:00: Slide 1 (Hook) + expectations
- 03:00‚Äì10:00: Slides 2‚Äì3 (Problem + Solution)
- 10:00‚Äì25:00: Slides 4‚Äì5 (Method & Evidence) + customer video
- 25:00‚Äì40:00: Live demo ‚Äî role prompt on a real task (end‚Äëuser demo)
- 40:00‚Äì55:00: Technical Deep‚ÄëDive (if requested) or Implementation Module
- 55:00‚Äì70:00: ROI Deep‚ÄëDive ‚Äî build client‚Äëspecific model (interactive)
- 70:00‚Äì80:00: Implementation path/timeline and commitments
- 80:00‚Äì90:00: Final Q&A, next steps, confirm follow‚Äëups, calendar a pilot start date

6) Transition Phrases (library to keep presenters fluent)
- From Problem ‚Üí Solution: ‚ÄúGiven those challenges, here‚Äôs a practical route to adoption.‚Äù
- From Solution ‚Üí How It Works: ‚ÄúThis is what that looks like day to day.‚Äù
- From How ‚Üí Proof: ‚ÄúBut does it actually deliver? Here‚Äôs the evidence.‚Äù
- From Proof ‚Üí Pricing: ‚ÄúSo here‚Äôs how we package this for teams your size.‚Äù
- From Pricing ‚Üí Integration: ‚ÄúA common question is how this connects to your stack ‚Äî here‚Äôs the approach.‚Äù
- From Integration ‚Üí Implementation: ‚ÄúAnd here‚Äôs the timeline to make it happen.‚Äù
- From Implementation ‚Üí ROI: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs translate those steps into the expected business return.‚Äù
- Closing: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre aligned, the next step is a focused Executive Briefing / Workshop ‚Äî shall we get a date in the diary?‚Äù

7) Engagement & Discovery Prompts (sprinkle throughout)
- Early: ‚ÄúWho in your team is already experimenting with AI? What‚Äôs worked/failed?‚Äù
- Mid: ‚ÄúWhich tasks, if automated or accelerated, would free up the most time?‚Äù
- ROI: ‚ÄúIf each of 150 users saved 20 hours/month, how would you value that time?‚Äù
- Implementation: ‚ÄúWho would own this internally? Who will be the champions?‚Äù

8) Objection Handling (short scripts)
- ‚ÄúWe tried training before and adoption failed.‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ focuses on role‚Äëbased, hands‚Äëon workshops, champion networks and measurable checkpoints ‚Äî not one‚Äëoff theory sessions.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúSecurity/data concerns.‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúWe design governance into prompts and workflows, avoid sharing PII with LLMs and can integrate with your existing data controls ‚Äî we‚Äôll show examples in the technical module.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúToo expensive.‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs run a quick ROI with your numbers ‚Äî you‚Äôll often see payback within months from time‚Äësavings alone.‚Äù

9) Materials Checklist & Tech Prep
- Materials to have ready: one‚Äëpager AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ overview, ROI calculator (excel/Google sheet), 2‚Äì3 client case slides, recorded customer testimonial, role‚Äëspecific prompt templates.
- Tech checks: screen share permission, customer sample doc (for live demo), backup screenshots, test video playback, ensure presenter has local copy of deck.

10) Post‚ÄëPresentation Follow‚Äëups (playbook steps)
- Immediate (within 24h): Send tailored recap (selected slides, ROI snapshot, proposed next dates).
- 48‚Äì72h: Book Exec Briefing/Workshop or send deeper materials (technical appendix, sample curriculum).
- Pre‚Äëengagement: Send short pre‚Äëwork survey to tailor focus (team size, main tools, top 3 use cases).

Use this playbook to keep presentations consistent, measurable and client‚Äëfocused. Customize slides and modules using the audience guide above; always close with a clear next step (date/cost/scope) and a commitment to build a client‚Äëspecific ROI or pilot plan during the next session.

If you‚Äôd like, I can:
- Produce a slide‚Äëby‚Äëslide speaker script for the 90‚Äëminute Executive Briefing.
- Build an ROI calculator template you can use live in briefings.
Which would you prefer next?

- Emphasize: Slides 3‚Äì5 (how it works, evidence), demo insertions, Implementation Module.
- Swap in: Role‚Äëspecific learning path examples and short live prompts/demo.
- Questions: ‚ÄúWhat repetitive tasks take most time? Who‚Äôs using which tools?‚Äù
- KPIs: time saved, workflows automated, number of daily tool actions reduced.

4) Visual & Demo Insertion Points (what to show and when)
- Slide 1 (Hook): Short animated 90‚Äëday journey graphic.
- Slide 3‚Äì4 (Method & How): Timeline/roadmap animation; visual of role paths.
- Slide 5 (Proof): Customer video clip (30‚Äì60s) or before/after metric cards.
- Slide 6 (Pricing): Package comparison table (interactive if shared screen).
- Slide 7 (Integration): Architecture diagram; live tour of a prompt library or template.
- Slide 8 (Timeline): Interactive 90‚Äëday planner (editable in session).
- Slide 9 (ROI): Live ROI calculator ‚Äî plug in the client‚Äôs numbers during briefing.
- During End‚Äëuser focus: Live demo of a prompt applied to a real task (copywriting, data summarisation, campaign brief creation) ‚Äî 3‚Äì5 minutes.
- Technical deep‚Äëdive: Live or recorded demo of sandbox integration, token management, or governance controls.
- Demo tech checks: Always test connectivity, video clips and any remote shares 10 minutes before session; have a screenshot backup.

5) Suggested Run Orders (ready‚Äëto‚Äëuse)
A. 30‚Äëminute Quick Pitch (ideal for discovery or initial outreach)
- 0:00‚Äì0:60s: Slide 1 (Hook) ‚Äî open & quick rapport
- 1:00‚Äì3:00: Slide 2 (Problem)
- 3:00‚Äì6:00: Slide 3 (Solution)
- 6:00‚Äì11:00: Slide 5 (Evidence) + quick visual
- 11:00‚Äì15:00: Slide 6 (Offer/Pricing)
- 15:00‚Äì18:00: Slide 9 (Quick ROI sketch)
- 18:00‚Äì23:00: Slide 10 (Why us & Next steps)
- 23:00‚Äì30:00: Q&A and agree next step (book Exec Briefing or Workshop)

B. 90‚Äëminute Executive Briefing (paid)
- 0:00‚Äì03:00: Slide 1 (Hook) + expectations
- 03:00‚Äì10:00: Slides 2‚Äì3 (Problem + Solution)
- 10:00‚Äì25:00: Slides 4‚Äì5 (Method & Evidence) + customer video
- 25:00‚Äì40:00: Live demo ‚Äî role prompt on a real task (end‚Äëuser demo)
- 40:00‚Äì55:00: Technical Deep‚ÄëDive (if requested) or Implementation Module
- 55:00‚Äì70:00: ROI Deep‚ÄëDive ‚Äî build client‚Äëspecific model (interactive)
- 70:00‚Äì80:00: Implementation path/timeline and commitments
- 80:00‚Äì90:00: Final Q&A, next steps, confirm follow‚Äëups, calendar a pilot start date

6) Transition Phrases (library to keep presenters fluent)
- From Problem ‚Üí Solution: ‚ÄúGiven those challenges, here‚Äôs a practical route to adoption.‚Äù
- From Solution ‚Üí How It Works: ‚ÄúThis is what that looks like day to day.‚Äù
- From How ‚Üí Proof: ‚ÄúBut does it actually deliver? Here‚Äôs the evidence.‚Äù
- From Proof ‚Üí Pricing: ‚ÄúSo here‚Äôs how we package this for teams your size.‚Äù
- From Pricing ‚Üí Integration: ‚ÄúA common question is how this connects to your stack ‚Äî here‚Äôs the approach.‚Äù
- From Integration ‚Üí Implementation: ‚ÄúAnd here‚Äôs the timeline to make it happen.‚Äù
- From Implementation ‚Üí ROI: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs translate those steps into the expected business return.‚Äù
- Closing: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre aligned, the next step is a focused Executive Briefing / Workshop ‚Äî shall we get a date in the diary?‚Äù

7) Engagement & Discovery Prompts (sprinkle throughout)
- Early: ‚ÄúWho in your team is already experimenting with AI? What‚Äôs worked/failed?‚Äù
- Mid: ‚ÄúWhich tasks, if automated or accelerated, would free up the most time?‚Äù
- ROI: ‚ÄúIf each of 150 users saved 20 hours/month, how would you value that time?‚Äù
- Implementation: ‚ÄúWho would own this internally? Who will be the champions?‚Äù

8) Objection Handling (short scripts)
- ‚ÄúWe tried training before and adoption failed.‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ focuses on role‚Äëbased, hands‚Äëon workshops, champion networks and measurable checkpoints ‚Äî not one‚Äëoff theory sessions.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúSecurity/data concerns.‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúWe design governance into prompts and workflows, avoid sharing PII with LLMs and can integrate with your existing data controls ‚Äî we‚Äôll show examples in the technical module.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúToo expensive.‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs run a quick ROI with your numbers ‚Äî you‚Äôll often see payback within months from time‚Äësavings alone.‚Äù

9) Materials Checklist & Tech Prep
- Materials to have ready: one‚Äëpager AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ overview, ROI calculator (excel/Google sheet), 2‚Äì3 client case slides, recorded customer testimonial, role‚Äëspecific prompt templates.
- Tech checks: screen share permission, customer sample doc (for live demo), backup screenshots, test video playback, ensure presenter has local copy of deck.

10) Post‚ÄëPresentation Follow‚Äëups (playbook steps)
- Immediate (within 24h): Send tailored recap (selected slides, ROI snapshot, proposed next dates).
- 48‚Äì72h: Book Exec Briefing/Workshop or send deeper materials (technical appendix, sample curriculum).
- Pre‚Äëengagement: Send short pre‚Äëwork survey to tailor focus (team size, main tools, top 3 use cases).

Use this playbook to keep presentations consistent, measurable and client‚Äëfocused. Customize slides and modules using the audience guide above; always close with a clear next step (date/cost/scope) and a commitment to build a client‚Äëspecific ROI or pilot plan during the next session.

If you‚Äôd like, I can:
- Produce a slide‚Äëby‚Äëslide speaker script for the 90‚Äëminute Executive Briefing.
- Build an ROI calculator template you can use live in briefings.
Which would you prefer next?

# AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ ‚Ä¢ Presentation Structure

AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ ‚Äî Sales Presentation Playbook
Purpose: A repeatable, modular sales presentation structure your team can use for 30‚Äëminute pitches, 90‚Äëminute executive briefings and longer workshops. Includes a 10‚Äëslide core deck outline (headlines + key talking points), optional deep‚Äëdive modules (technical, ROI, implementation), audience customization guidance, and visual/demo insertion points. Each slide includes time allocations and transition phrases.

1) Core 10‚ÄëSlide Deck (compact + extendable)
Notes: Two timing schemas shown per slide ‚Äî Quick Pitch (30m total: ~20‚Äì25m presentation + 5‚Äì10m Q&A) and Executive Briefing (90m total: ~60‚Äì75m presentation + 15‚Äì30m interactive work/Q&A). Use the short times for cold calls / discovery meetings; use extended times during paid Executive Briefings.

Slide 1 ‚Äî Title & Hook
- Time: Quick 1 min / Exec 3 min
- Headline: AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢ ‚Äî Turn your whole team into AI power users in 90 days
- Key talking points: One‚Äëline value prop (90% using AI weekly within 30 days; 20+ hours saved per person/month); who we are (Brilliant Noise, Brighton B‚ÄëCorp, clients like adidas/BMW/Nestl√©); what this session will cover.
- Visual/demo cue: Brand slide with 1‚Äëline animation of the 90‚Äëday journey.
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs why this matters for your team right now.‚Äù

Slide 2 ‚Äî Problem (Context & Pain)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 5 min
- Headline: Adoption stalls ‚Äî pilots, tool fragmentation and lack of role training
- Key talking points: Typical failure modes (pilot fatigue, tool overload, skills gap); business consequences (wasted time, lost agility, missed revenue/marketing performance).
- Audience question: ‚ÄúWhich of these sounds like your team?‚Äù
- Transition: ‚ÄúSo what does success look like? A practical route from talk to daily use.‚Äù

Slide 3 ‚Äî Solution Overview
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 6 min
- Headline: AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢: Test‚ÄëLearn‚ÄëLead‚Ñ¢ for practical AI adoption
- Key talking points: Program components (exec alignment, role‚Äëbased workshops, progress tracking); modular curriculum; outcome promise (90% active use, 20+ hours saved).
- Visual: 3‚Äëstep Test‚ÄëLearn‚ÄëLead‚Ñ¢ graphic.
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how the programme works in practice.‚Äù

Slide 4 ‚Äî How It Works (Methodology)
- Time: Quick 3 min / Exec 8 min
- Headline: Hands‚Äëon curriculum, role paths and real work scenarios
- Key talking points: Sprint structure (Executive Briefing, Team Workshop Day, Sprint Package); role‚Äëspecific learning paths; measurement framework and success metrics.
- Demo cue: Slide with sample week‚Äëby‚Äëweek timeline.
- Transition: ‚ÄúLet me show evidence this actually delivers.‚Äù

Slide 5 ‚Äî Evidence & Outcomes (Proof)
- Time: Quick 3 min / Exec 8 min
- Headline: Measurable gains ‚Äî case evidence and client outcomes
- Key talking points: Case snapshots (adidas/BMW/Nestl√©) with outcomes (hours saved, adoption %); testimonials/quote; metrics we track (usage, productivity hours saved, campaign lift).
- Visual/demo cue: Before/after metrics dashboard screenshot or short customer video (30‚Äì60s).
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what you get when you buy AI‚ÄëB‚ÄëC‚Ñ¢.‚Äù

Slide 6 ‚Äî Deliverables & Pricing
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 5 min
- Headline: Offerings: Executive Briefing (¬£2k) ‚Ä¢ Team Workshop Day (¬£8.8k) ‚Ä¢ Complete Sprint (¬£17.5k)
- Key talking points: What each package contains, who it‚Äôs for, typical outcomes per package, expected timeline to first impact (30 days for weekly use).
- Transition: ‚ÄúNow let‚Äôs cover how this integrates with your systems and people.‚Äù

Slide 7 ‚Äî Integration & Security (High‚Äëlevel)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 6 min
- Headline: Practical integration ‚Äî tools, data & governance
- Key talking points: We‚Äôre not a systems integrator; we enable people to use existing tools safely (prompt frameworks, data handling rules); basic architecture/integration touchpoints; B‚ÄëCorp values and responsible AI practice.
- Demo cue: Architecture sketch + governance checklist.
- Transition: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how we make adoption real in day‚Äëto‚Äëday work.‚Äù

Slide 8 ‚Äî Typical Implementation Path & Timeline
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 6 min
- Headline: From briefing to org‚Äëwide use ‚Äî a 90‚Äëday path
- Key talking points: Milestones (exec alignment, workshops, role pilots, measurement); success checkpoints; client responsibilities and Brilliant Noise support.
- Visual: 90‚Äëday roadmap with key deliverables.
- Transition: ‚ÄúFrequently asked question: what ROI can you expect?‚Äù

Slide 9 ‚Äî ROI & Business Case (brief)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 8 min
- Headline: Rapid productivity gains that show ROI fast
- Key talking points: Typical ROI math (hours saved per user √ó user count √ó value/hour); evidence from pilots; payback examples for 150+ employee organisations.
- Demo cue: Simple ROI calculator mockup (interactive if exec wants numbers).
- Transition: ‚ÄúCommon questions ‚Äî and quickly, why pick Brilliant Noise?‚Äù

Slide 10 ‚Äî Why Brilliant Noise & Next Steps (Close + CTA)
- Time: Quick 2 min / Exec 5‚Äì8 min
- Headline: Brighton boutique, global pedigree ‚Äî commercial focus + ethics
- Key talking points: Differentiators (Test‚ÄëLearn‚ÄëLead‚Ñ¢, B‚ÄëCorp, leadership experience, client list); recommended next step (book Executive Briefing or complete Sprint); timeline for onboarding; logistics/pricing recap.
- CTA: Propose dates/options, ask for commitment to next step.
- Transition to Q&A: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love your questions ‚Äî and to tailor the next session to what matters most for you.‚Äù

2) Optional Deep‚ÄëDive Modules (plug into Slide 4‚Äì9 as needed)
Include module purpose, duration, when to use, contents, visuals and transition phrases.

A. Technical Deep‚ÄëDive (for CTOs/IT)
- Duration: 20‚Äì35 minutes (add to 90m session or separate 45m follow‚Äëup)
- Objective: Show architecture, integrations, security, vendor choices and scale considerations.
- Contents: integration options (SaaS tools, LLM access), data governance & PII handling, SSO/permissions, orchestration (prompt libraries + templates), scalability & change control.
- Visuals: system diagrams, data flow, security checklist, integration matrix.
- Trigger: Asked by technical stakeholders or when data access is complex.
- Transition phrase: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs step under the hood to show how this fits your stack and governance.‚Äù

B. ROI & Business Case Deep‚ÄëDive (for CFO/CMO)
- Duration: 20‚Äì30 minutes
- Objective: Build a tailored ROI model and payback scenario.
- Contents: Inputs needed (users, roles, current time spent on routine tasks, average value per hour), sensitivity analysis, case study math, risk/assumption list.
- Visuals: Interactive ROI calculator, scenario slides, payback timeline.
- Trigger: Execs asking about cost/benefit or procurement stakeholders.
- Transition phrase: ‚ÄúNow we‚Äôll translate adoption into hard numbers for your organisation.‚Äù

C. Implementation & Change Management Module (for HR/Operations/Change leads)
- Duration: 20‚Äì30 minutes

- Contents: Role‚Äëspecific curricula, workshop formats, coaching/certification, measurement dashboard, adoption playbook (champions, comms, incentives).

- Trigger: When customer cites culture/resistance or needs rollout planning.
- Transition phrase: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs the sequence and people plan that turns training into habit.‚Äù

Quick rules for tailoring language, slides to emphasize, suggested questions to ask, and KPIs to highlight.

A. Executives (CMO, CDO, C‚Äësuite)

- KPIs to highlight: time saved per user, adoption %, campaign performance lift, payback months.

B. Technical (CTO, Head of Data, Security)
- Tone: Precise, pragmatic, compliance‚Äëfocused.

- KPIs: data risk mitigations, latency, uptime, integration effort estimates.

C. End‚Äëusers / Practitioners (Marketers, Product Owners)

- Questions: ‚ÄúWhat repetitive tasks take most time? Who‚Äôs using which tools?‚Äù

sections.AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ ‚Ä¢ Discovery Qualification:
Framework: AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ Sales Discovery & Qualification
Purpose: Rapidly determine fit and likelihood of success for AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ with CMOs/CDOs/Innovation execs at medium‚Üílarge enterprises. Deliverable: 10 high-impact discovery questions (mapped to BANT + MEDDIC), clear red flags for disqualification, an ideal-customer scoring model (1‚Äì10), and prescriptive next steps by score.

1) Ten discovery questions ‚Äî organised by BANT / MEDDIC (each question: mapping, why it matters, what a strong answer looks like, what‚Äôs a red-flag answer)
Note: Use these in a 30‚Äì45 minute executive discovery. Invite the likely economic buyer + potential champion; ask for an org chart & top business metrics as pre-read.

A. Budget (BANT) / Metrics (MEDDIC)
1. ‚ÄúWhat would success look like if your teams were using AI daily in 30‚Äì90 days? Which KPIs would you expect to move, and by how much?‚Äù
- Maps to: Budget (willingness to invest), Metrics (value)
- Why: Ties product outputs (90% weekly use, 20+ hrs saved) to their financial/operational goals.
- Strong answer: Specific KPIs (hours saved, cost per campaign, time-to-market, churn/retention uplift) with target magnitudes and ownership.
- Red flag: Vague ‚Äúwe want to be more innovative‚Äù with no measurable metrics.

B. Authority (BANT) / Economic Buyer (MEDDIC)
2. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs the executive who must sign off on learning / people development spends, and who will champion this internally?‚Äù
- Maps to: Authority, Economic Buyer, Champion
- Why: Identifies decision-maker and internal sponsor.
- Strong answer: Names, timeline for approval, champion in marketing/innovation with authority to allocate budgets.
- Red flag: No named decision-maker or ‚Äúwe‚Äôll need to ask procurement‚Äù with no internal sponsor.

C. Need / Pain (BANT & MEDDIC ‚Äì Identify Pain)
3. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the biggest productivity or capability gap across your marketing/product/innovation teams that you think AI could fix?‚Äù
- Maps to: Need/Pain, Identify Pain
- Why: Validates urgency & alignment with AI-B-C‚Äôs outcome-driven promise.
- Strong answer: Explicit pain like campaign bottlenecks, agency reliance, long content cycles, measurable wasted hours.
- Red flag: No clear operational pain or belief that existing processes are ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù

D. Timing (BANT) / Decision Process (MEDDIC)
4. ‚ÄúWhen do you need measurable change in place‚Äîand what‚Äôs your decision process/timeline for vendor selection?‚Äù
- Maps to: Timing, Decision Process
- Why: Confirms whether they can meet our 30‚Äì90 day adoption window and procurement duration.
- Strong answer: 30‚Äì90 day expectation, clear decision steps, a target decision date within 30‚Äì60 days.
- Red flag: Procurement timeline >6 months or indecisive process.

E. Decision Criteria (MEDDIC)
5. ‚ÄúWhat criteria will you use to decide between training/enablement partners (e.g., case studies, metrics, security, value for money)?‚Äù
- Maps to: Decision Criteria
- Why: Reveals must-haves (security, vendor pedigree, ROI proof).
- Strong answer: Prioritises demonstrable ROI, role-specific outcomes, references from CPG/consumer brands.
- Red flag: Criteria are unrealistic (lowest price only) or dominated by internal politics.

F. Competition / Existing Tools (MEDDIC)
6. ‚ÄúWhat AI tools, learning platforms or pilots are already in place? If adoption stalled, why?‚Äù
- Maps to: Competition, Technical Fit
- Why: Identifies fragmentation and where AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ can complement or replace efforts.
- Strong answer: Some pilots but no role-specific training or outcome measurement; appetite to consolidate.
- Red flag: Heavy enterprise contracts preventing new training or legal bans on third-party AI tools.

G. Economic Value / ROI (MEDDIC ‚Äì Metrics)
7. ‚ÄúDo you have an expected ROI or cost-savings target for a programme like this? How does training & productivity factor into your P&L?‚Äù
- Maps to: Metrics / Economic Buyer
- Why: Confirms financial orientation and ease of business case creation.
- Strong answer: Has a target (e.g., reduce agency spend by X, productivity savings equating to Y ¬£/month).
- Red flag: No interest in quantifying ROI or inability to see productivity as value.

H. Champion & Adoption (MEDDIC)
8. ‚ÄúWho inside the team would be the day-to-day lead/champion for adoption and progress tracking?‚Äù
- Maps to: Champion, Identify Pain
- Why: Adoption depends on an operational champion for roll-out & measurement.
- Strong answer: Named training lead / L&D partner / marketing ops manager ready to own progress tracking.
- Red flag: No internal resource or expectation that vendor will do everything with no client involvement.

I. Legal / Data / IT (Technical Fit)
9. ‚ÄúAre there regulatory, legal or IT constraints (data residency, IP, approved vendors) that could block hands-on AI training?‚Äù
- Maps to: Technical / Compliance risk
- Why: Hands-on workshops require access to tools/data and clearances.
- Strong answer: Minor constraints; willing to run redacted or sandboxed sessions and sign an NDA.
- Red flag: Blanket ban on external AI tools, no willingness to allow role-based sandboxing.

J. Budget & Funding Source (BANT)
10. ‚ÄúDo you have an allocated training/capability budget or will this be funded from transformation/innovation/marketing budgets?‚Äù
- Maps to: Budget
- Why: Confirms where money comes from and whether price points (¬£2k/¬£8.8k/¬£17.5k) are feasible.
- Strong answer: Budget line exists in L&D/marketing/innovation or clear approval route for these amounts.
- Red flag: No budget and no sponsorship to free funds this quarter/next quarter.

2) Red-flag indicators for disqualification (fast disqualifiers)
- Company size <50 employees (product targets 50+; ideal 150+).  
- No named economic buyer / no internal champion after two outreach attempts.  
- Procurement or legal procurement timeline > 6 months for small/medium programmes.  
- No training/development budget and no plan to reallocate funds.  
- Legal/IT prohibits any external AI tooling or hands-on sessions (cannot sandbox).  
- No measurable business metrics or refusal to quantify expected outcomes.  
- Stakeholder belief that AI is ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù with no urgency; no operational pain.  
- Executive energy focused elsewhere for 12+ months (e.g., M&A, major restructure).  
- Competing enterprise contracts that lock training/agency spend and bar new vendors.  
- Repeated inability to produce the list of teams/roles that would attend within 3 contact cycles.

3) Ideal Customer Scoring criteria (1‚Äì10 per criterion) ‚Äî what to score and how
Score each criterion 1‚Äì10 (1 = very weak / disqualifying, 10 = ideal). Sum or weight (see weighting guidance) to create a normalized score out of 100, or average to map to a 1‚Äì10 overall qualification score.

Recommended scoring dimensions (with weighting suggestions for total score; weights sum = 100%):
- Strategic Fit / Industry & Size (15%): Company 150+ employees, consumer/global brand = high score.
- Urgency / Pain (20%): Clear productivity or capability gap tied to KPIs.
- Budget Availability (15%): Existing training budget or approved spend.
- Economic Buyer / Authority (10%): Named decision-maker and alignment.
- Executive Sponsorship (10%): Exec alignment with 90-day adoption goal.
- Champion & Adoption Capacity (10%): Named operational champion ready to lead roll-out.
- Timeline / Decision Process (8%): Decision within 30‚Äì60 days; procurement straightforward.
- Technical / Legal Fit (7%): Sandbox, acceptable vendor security/compliance posture.
- ROI Clarity / Metrics (5%): Specific KPIs and measurable targets.

Scoring guidance examples (per criterion):
- 9‚Äì10: Ideal (e.g., 5000-50k employees, named CMO champion, budget approved, decision in 30 days)
- 6‚Äì8: Good (e.g., 150‚Äì1000 employees, budget likely, decision in 60 days)
- 3‚Äì5: Marginal (e.g., 50‚Äì149 employees, budget unsure, procurement may delay)
- 1‚Äì2: Poor (e.g., <50 employees, no budget, procurement >6 months, legal block)

Example calculation (quick method):
- Rate each criterion 1‚Äì10 ‚Üí multiply by weight ‚Üí sum ‚Üí normalized to a 0‚Äì100 score.
- Map to 1‚Äì10 by dividing by 10 or use direct ranges (below).

4) Interpret scores & recommended next steps (actionable playbook)

A. Score 85‚Äì100 (Overall 9‚Äì10 / ‚ÄúChampion Deal ‚Äî Close & Scale‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Excellent fit, budget and buyer aligned, timeline tight, champion in place.
- Immediate actions (within 48‚Äì72 hrs):
  - Send tailored commercial proposal: Offer Complete Sprint (¬£17,500) with a 30‚Äì60 day start window.
  - Book Executive Briefing within 7‚Äì14 days (paid engagement) as a contractual kickoff and discovery step.
  - Prepare a short bespoke one-page ROI case using their KPIs (use pre-call data).
  - Identify implementation squad: champion, IT contact, learning lead; propose dates for 2 workshops.
  - Legal/procurement: push a standard SOW + NDA with a 2‚Äì3 week procurement timetable. Offer fast-track contracting template.
- Upsell play: Add 3-month adoption support & success measurement add-on.

B. Score 70‚Äì84 (Overall 7‚Äì8 / ‚ÄúQualified ‚Äî Run Pilot & Prove Value‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Good fit; some approvals or technical details to iron out.
- Actions (within 1 week):
  - Propose a Team Workshop Day (¬£8,800) as a pilot for a high-impact team (e.g., core marketing squad).
  - Offer Executive Briefing (¬£2,000) to secure executive alignment prior to pilot.
  - Provide case studies from similar clients (adidas, Nestl√©) and a sample 30-day KPI dashboard.
  - Agree a simple success metric (e.g., X hours saved across Pilot cohort) and a KPI review date at 30 days.
  - Get procurement/legal pre-reads to confirm sandboxing/permissions.
- Nurture plan: If pilot metrics achieved, propose Complete Sprint and enterprise roll-out.

C. Score 50‚Äì69 (Overall 5‚Äì6 / ‚ÄúProspect ‚Äî Nurture & Educate‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Fit possible but obstacles (budget, timeline, exec buy-in).
- Actions:
  - Recommend Executive Briefing (¬£2,000) as low-friction first step to build the business case.
  - Offer a tailored ROI model at no cost (limited scope) to help internal champion sell-up.
  - Send a 6‚Äì8 week nurture plan: monthly executive insights, 30-minute case-study demos, 1-page ROI templates.
  - Ask for a follow-up decision review date and checklist of procurement/legal blockers to resolve.
- Gate: If after Executive Briefing there is still no internal budget or sponsor, move to long-term nurture.

D. Score 30‚Äì49 (Overall 3‚Äì4 / ‚ÄúLow Probability ‚Äî Conditional Nurture‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Either company size marginal, or fundamental blockers (procurement delays, legal bans).
- Actions:
  - Offer to be a resource: send on-demand resources ‚Äî recorded Executive Briefing, ROI templates, short playbooks.
  - Keep in a 6‚Äì12 month nurture track; check back when budget cycles open or when legal constraints change.
  - Capture key changes needed to re-qualify (budget approval, new sponsor, decision date).
- Close politely if no movement after two quarters; move to marketing nurture.

E. Score 1‚Äì29 (Overall 1‚Äì2 / ‚ÄúDisqualify‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Clear disqualifiers present (legal ban, <50 employees, no budget & no intent).
- Actions:
  - Disqualify from active pipeline but offer resources: invite to newsletter, send recorded briefing & case studies.
  - Log reason for disqualification and next review date (e.g., 6‚Äì12 months).
  - Optional: if company is small but influential, propose community/free webinar entry points.

5) Practical guidance for sellers (scripts, timelines & attachments)
- Discovery call length: 30‚Äì45 mins with the economic buyer + champion. If only a champion, book for 45 mins and aim to get decision-maker on the Exec Briefing.
- Pre-reads to request: org chart for marketing & product teams, top 3 KPIs they want to impact, existing AI/tooling inventory.
- Suggested follow-up sequence on a strong lead (score >70):
  1) Send tailored proposal + SOW template within 48 hours.
  2) Book Exec Briefing within 7‚Äì14 days.
  3) Post-briefing: Pilot Workshop within 14‚Äì30 days.
  4) KPI review at 30 days; conversion to Complete Sprint within 60‚Äì90 days.
- Contract acceleration tactics: include a fixed-scope SOW for the Complete Sprint, demo of measurable outcomes from a similar client, two reference calls within 48 hrs, and optional payment milestones.
- Template asks for champion: ‚ÄúCan you introduce me to the person who will run day-to-day adoption and sign off on attendance lists?‚Äù Use this to convert Authority score.

6) One-page win criteria (use this in proposals & exec briefings)
- Commitment: Executive sponsor identified + budget approval to run pilot or sprint.
- People: Minimum cohort of 20 people for Team Workshop or defined list of 50‚Äì150 for enterprise Sprint.
- Tech: Sandbox or safe tooling environment for hands-on labs.
- Metrics: Agreed KPI (e.g., 20+ hours saved per participant / X% reduction in time-to-market).
- Timeline: Pilot or Exec Briefing scheduled within 30 days; pilot KPI review at 30 days.

Wrap-up
- Use the 10 questions as the backbone of your first two calls; score live and decide path (Close/Pilot/Nurture/Disqualify).  
- Keep the conversation outcome-focused (tie to the 90% weekly use & 20+ hrs saved claims) and always seek a named champion + a decision timescale.  
If you want, I can convert the scoring template into a one-click spreadsheet you can use during calls and a short email template per next-step outcome (high/mid/low). Which would you like next?

- Competing enterprise contracts that lock training/agency spend and bar new vendors.  
- Repeated inability to produce the list of teams/roles that would attend within 3 contact cycles.

3) Ideal Customer Scoring criteria (1‚Äì10 per criterion) ‚Äî what to score and how
Score each criterion 1‚Äì10 (1 = very weak / disqualifying, 10 = ideal). Sum or weight (see weighting guidance) to create a normalized score out of 100, or average to map to a 1‚Äì10 overall qualification score.

Recommended scoring dimensions (with weighting suggestions for total score; weights sum = 100%):
- Strategic Fit / Industry & Size (15%): Company 150+ employees, consumer/global brand = high score.
- Urgency / Pain (20%): Clear productivity or capability gap tied to KPIs.
- Budget Availability (15%): Existing training budget or approved spend.
- Economic Buyer / Authority (10%): Named decision-maker and alignment.
- Executive Sponsorship (10%): Exec alignment with 90-day adoption goal.
- Champion & Adoption Capacity (10%): Named operational champion ready to lead roll-out.
- Timeline / Decision Process (8%): Decision within 30‚Äì60 days; procurement straightforward.
- Technical / Legal Fit (7%): Sandbox, acceptable vendor security/compliance posture.
- ROI Clarity / Metrics (5%): Specific KPIs and measurable targets.

Scoring guidance examples (per criterion):
- 9‚Äì10: Ideal (e.g., 5000-50k employees, named CMO champion, budget approved, decision in 30 days)
- 6‚Äì8: Good (e.g., 150‚Äì1000 employees, budget likely, decision in 60 days)
- 3‚Äì5: Marginal (e.g., 50‚Äì149 employees, budget unsure, procurement may delay)
- 1‚Äì2: Poor (e.g., <50 employees, no budget, procurement >6 months, legal block)

Example calculation (quick method):
- Rate each criterion 1‚Äì10 ‚Üí multiply by weight ‚Üí sum ‚Üí normalized to a 0‚Äì100 score.
- Map to 1‚Äì10 by dividing by 10 or use direct ranges (below).

4) Interpret scores & recommended next steps (actionable playbook)

A. Score 85‚Äì100 (Overall 9‚Äì10 / ‚ÄúChampion Deal ‚Äî Close & Scale‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Excellent fit, budget and buyer aligned, timeline tight, champion in place.
- Immediate actions (within 48‚Äì72 hrs):
  - Send tailored commercial proposal: Offer Complete Sprint (¬£17,500) with a 30‚Äì60 day start window.
  - Book Executive Briefing within 7‚Äì14 days (paid engagement) as a contractual kickoff and discovery step.
  - Prepare a short bespoke one-page ROI case using their KPIs (use pre-call data).
  - Identify implementation squad: champion, IT contact, learning lead; propose dates for 2 workshops.
  - Legal/procurement: push a standard SOW + NDA with a 2‚Äì3 week procurement timetable. Offer fast-track contracting template.
- Upsell play: Add 3-month adoption support & success measurement add-on.

B. Score 70‚Äì84 (Overall 7‚Äì8 / ‚ÄúQualified ‚Äî Run Pilot & Prove Value‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Good fit; some approvals or technical details to iron out.
- Actions (within 1 week):
  - Propose a Team Workshop Day (¬£8,800) as a pilot for a high-impact team (e.g., core marketing squad).
  - Offer Executive Briefing (¬£2,000) to secure executive alignment prior to pilot.
  - Provide case studies from similar clients (adidas, Nestl√©) and a sample 30-day KPI dashboard.
  - Agree a simple success metric (e.g., X hours saved across Pilot cohort) and a KPI review date at 30 days.
  - Get procurement/legal pre-reads to confirm sandboxing/permissions.
- Nurture plan: If pilot metrics achieved, propose Complete Sprint and enterprise roll-out.

C. Score 50‚Äì69 (Overall 5‚Äì6 / ‚ÄúProspect ‚Äî Nurture & Educate‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Fit possible but obstacles (budget, timeline, exec buy-in).
- Actions:
  - Recommend Executive Briefing (¬£2,000) as low-friction first step to build the business case.
  - Offer a tailored ROI model at no cost (limited scope) to help internal champion sell-up.
  - Send a 6‚Äì8 week nurture plan: monthly executive insights, 30-minute case-study demos, 1-page ROI templates.
  - Ask for a follow-up decision review date and checklist of procurement/legal blockers to resolve.
- Gate: If after Executive Briefing there is still no internal budget or sponsor, move to long-term nurture.

D. Score 30‚Äì49 (Overall 3‚Äì4 / ‚ÄúLow Probability ‚Äî Conditional Nurture‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Either company size marginal, or fundamental blockers (procurement delays, legal bans).
- Actions:
  - Offer to be a resource: send on-demand resources ‚Äî recorded Executive Briefing, ROI templates, short playbooks.
  - Keep in a 6‚Äì12 month nurture track; check back when budget cycles open or when legal constraints change.
  - Capture key changes needed to re-qualify (budget approval, new sponsor, decision date).
- Close politely if no movement after two quarters; move to marketing nurture.

E. Score 1‚Äì29 (Overall 1‚Äì2 / ‚ÄúDisqualify‚Äù)
- Diagnosis: Clear disqualifiers present (legal ban, <50 employees, no budget & no intent).
- Actions:
  - Disqualify from active pipeline but offer resources: invite to newsletter, send recorded briefing & case studies.
  - Log reason for disqualification and next review date (e.g., 6‚Äì12 months).
  - Optional: if company is small but influential, propose community/free webinar entry points.

5) Practical guidance for sellers (scripts, timelines & attachments)
- Discovery call length: 30‚Äì45 mins with the economic buyer + champion. If only a champion, book for 45 mins and aim to get decision-maker on the Exec Briefing.
- Pre-reads to request: org chart for marketing & product teams, top 3 KPIs they want to impact, existing AI/tooling inventory.
- Suggested follow-up sequence on a strong lead (score >70):
  1) Send tailored proposal + SOW template within 48 hours.
  2) Book Exec Briefing within 7‚Äì14 days.
  3) Post-briefing: Pilot Workshop within 14‚Äì30 days.
  4) KPI review at 30 days; conversion to Complete Sprint within 60‚Äì90 days.
- Contract acceleration tactics: include a fixed-scope SOW for the Complete Sprint, demo of measurable outcomes from a similar client, two reference calls within 48 hrs, and optional payment milestones.
- Template asks for champion: ‚ÄúCan you introduce me to the person who will run day-to-day adoption and sign off on attendance lists?‚Äù Use this to convert Authority score.

6) One-page win criteria (use this in proposals & exec briefings)
- Commitment: Executive sponsor identified + budget approval to run pilot or sprint.
- People: Minimum cohort of 20 people for Team Workshop or defined list of 50‚Äì150 for enterprise Sprint.
- Tech: Sandbox or safe tooling environment for hands-on labs.
- Metrics: Agreed KPI (e.g., 20+ hours saved per participant / X% reduction in time-to-market).
- Timeline: Pilot or Exec Briefing scheduled within 30 days; pilot KPI review at 30 days.

Wrap-up
- Use the 10 questions as the backbone of your first two calls; score live and decide path (Close/Pilot/Nurture/Disqualify).  
- Keep the conversation outcome-focused (tie to the 90% weekly use & 20+ hrs saved claims) and always seek a named champion + a decision timescale.  
If you want, I can convert the scoring template into a one-click spreadsheet you can use during calls and a short email template per next-step outcome (high/mid/low). Which would you like next?

sections.AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ ‚Ä¢ Qa Prep:
1) What is your Total Addressable Market and which segment are you targeting first?
Answer: We target the global enterprise marketing and product teams within mid-to-large consumer brands (150‚Äì50,000 employees), a subset of the enterprise L&D and digital transformation market worth multi-billions and growing rapidly as AI adoption accelerates.  
Follow-up: I‚Äôll send our TAM deck and ICP prioritisation slides for your review.

2) How do you differentiate from McKinsey/BCG, big agencies and pure tech implementers?
Answer: We combine hands-on AI upskilling, marketing transformation pedigree and boutique agility‚Äîpractical, role-specific training that delivers measurable productivity (90% weekly use in 30 days, 20+ hrs saved/month) rather than strategy alone or pure tooling.  
Follow-up: See our competitor matrix and three recent client case studies showing comparative outcomes.

3) What is your business model and primary revenue streams?
Answer: We sell tiered, outcome-focused programs‚ÄîExecutive Briefings (¬£2k), Team Workshop Days (¬£8.8k) and Complete Sprints (¬£17.5k)‚Äîwith follow-on retainers for implementation and capability support.  
Follow-up: I can share our pricing catalogue and example engagement revenue map.

4) Can this product scale beyond one-off workshops‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the path to recurring revenue and productisation?
Answer: Yes; we scale via modular curricula, train-the-trainer and subscription success plans that convert one-off workshops into ongoing capability contracts and platformised assets for repeatable delivery.  
Follow-up: Let me show you our subscription roadmap and pilot-to-retainer conversion metrics.

5) What are your unit economics ‚Äî CAC, LTV and payback period?
Answer: Our model is services-led with strong repeat rates and favourable LTV/CAC driven by enterprise renewals and cross-sell, delivering payback within a single annual contract cycle for most deals.  
Follow-up: I‚Äôll share the anonymised cohort LTV/CAC and payback schedule from our CRM.

6) What gross margins do engagements deliver and where are the capacity constraints?
Answer: Workshops and sprints deliver healthy professional-services gross margins (highly variable by mix), with the primary capacity constraint being senior trainer time which we manage via standardised modules and accredited partners.  
Follow-up: I can provide margin models by engagement type and our capacity/partner plan.

7) Tell us about the founding and delivery team ‚Äî do you have enterprise credibility and execution depth?
Answer: Founders have 15+ years in digital transformation and a track record with global brands (adidas, BMW, Nestl√©), supported by a senior delivery team of AI practitioners and experienced marketing strategists.  
Follow-up: Request bios and three client references and we‚Äôll send them over.

8) How will you recruit and scale trainers while preserving quality and brand reputation?
Answer: We use a phased hiring and accreditation approach‚Äîhire senior leads, standardise content, certify internal trainers and trusted partners, and enforce quality via live audits and client KPIs.  
Follow-up: I can share our trainer accreditation playbook and QA checklist.

9) What is your go-to-market motion and typical enterprise sales cycle?
Answer: GTM combines direct enterprise sales to CMOs/CDOs, partner referrals from agencies/tech vendors, and targetted executive briefings; average sales cycles are 6‚Äì12 weeks for pilot workshops and 3‚Äì6 months for large sprints.  
Follow-up: I‚Äôll send the GTM funnel metrics and a sample pipeline of active opportunities.

10) What are the biggest execution risks and how do you mitigate them?
Answer: Top risks are delivery scalability, client outcome variability and fast-moving competition; we mitigate via standardised curricula, outcome SLAs, client success metrics and continuous product iteration from our Test-Learn-Lead‚Ñ¢ process.  
Follow-up: See our risk register and mitigation roadmap‚ÄîI‚Äôll share the latest version.

11) How defensible is your IP‚Äîdo you have proprietary content, methods, or tech?
Answer: Our defensibility is built on a proprietary curriculum, role-specific playbooks, client-tested workflows and B2B relationships rather than patents, making it hard-to-copy in practice though not fully patentable.  
Follow-up: I can provide anonymised curriculum samples and explain our client lock-in mechanisms.

12) How do you handle client data, privacy and compliance for enterprise customers?
Answer: We operate strict data-handling protocols, use secure tooling, sign enterprise NDAs, and advise clients on privacy-by-design and vendor configurations to ensure GDPR and sector-specific compliance.  
Follow-up: I‚Äôll share our data-processing addendum, security checklist and SOC/ISO evidence where available.

sections.AI-B-C‚Ñ¢ ‚Ä¢ Pricing Roi:
Business Model Canvas (condensed)
- Key Partners: LMS & LLM providers (OpenAI, Anthropic), HR/L&D buyers, channel partners (regional consultancies), enterprise sales agencies.
- Key Activities: executive briefings, team workshops, 90‚Äëday sprints, content creation, customer success & measurement.
- Key Resources: senior AI consultants, facilitators, modular curriculum, analytics dashboard, B‚ÄëCorp brand.
- Cost Structure: direct delivery costs (consultants, travel, licences), content amortisation, sales & marketing, platform & overhead.
- Revenue Streams: one‚Äëoff training fees (Exec ¬£2k, Workshop ¬£8.8k, Sprint ¬£17.5k), recurring support/subscription, premium custom projects, licensing.

Unit Economics (assumptions shown)
Assumptions: senior consultant fully‚Äëloaded ¬£120/hr; junior facilitator ¬£60/hr; travel/materials/platform amortised per engagement.

1) Exec Briefing (90 mins) ‚Äî Price ¬£2,000
- Direct cost: prep (4h senior) ¬£480 + delivery (1.5h senior) ¬£180 + admin ¬£50 + travel/materials ¬£240 = ¬£950
- Gross margin: ¬£1,050 (53%)

2) Team Workshop Day ‚Äî Price ¬£8,800
- Direct cost: prep (8h senior + 8h junior) ¬£1,440 + delivery (8h senior+8h junior) ¬£1,440 + travel ¬£300 + materials/platform ¬£350 = ¬£3,530
- Gross margin: ¬£5,270 (60%)

3) Complete Sprint ‚Äî Price ¬£17,500
- Direct cost: exec + 2 workshops + 30‚Äëday support + content amortisation ‚âà ¬£11,110
- Gross margin: ¬£6,390 (37%)

Breakeven (monthly)
- Fixed costs (allocated to product): 2 FTEs (¬£16k), marketing ¬£4k, platform ¬£1k = ¬£21k/month.
- Using a representative monthly mix (1 Sprint, 2 Workshops, 2 Execs): contribution ‚âà ¬£19k on revenue ¬£39.1k ‚Äî short of fixed costs.
- Target monthly revenue to break even ‚âà ¬£43‚Äì45k (roughly one Sprint + 2 Workshops + 3 Execs). Action: aim for ¬£540k ARR to cover current headcount and growth.

Pricing Strategy
- Model & justification: value‚Äëbased tiering ‚Äî low‚Äëfriction Exec (¬£2k) to openthe door; Workshops (¬£8.8k) for team transformation; Sprint (¬£17.5k) as value bundle. Prices align to delivered ROI (see ROI section) and boutique premium positioning.
- Competitive positioning: premium boutique vs large consultancies ‚Äî charge 25‚Äì40% below top consultancies but above mass e‚Äëlearning; emphasise bespoke facilitation, measurable productivity gains, B‚ÄëCorp values.
- Price testing framework: run cohort A/B tests on discount (10% vs 0%) to measure conversion lift; pilot ‚Äúvalue‚Äëshare‚Äù offer (reduced upfront, bonus on realised savings) for 5 clients; track CAC payback, NPS, time‚Äëto‚Äëvalue. Use landing page price experiments and win/loss interviews.

Scalability Analysis
- Constraints: senior facilitator capacity, customisation time, travel, sales cycle.
- Path to scale: productise modules (off‚Äëthe‚Äëshelf playbooks), build digital self‚Äëserve course for 70% of content, create Train‚Äëthe‚ÄëTrainer (TtT) programme to scale reach, license curriculum to HR partners.
- Automation opportunities: onboarding bots, automated skills assessments, analytics dashboards for ROI tracking, templated prompts and role‚Äëspecific libraries to reduce prep from hours to minutes.

ROI Framework (customer perspective ‚Äî training 30 people)
Assumptions vary by scenario: per‚Äëperson hourly value and hours saved.

1) Conservative
- 10 hrs saved/month; ¬£35/hr => ¬£350/month/person ‚Üí 30 people = ¬£10,500/month (¬£126k/year)
- Payback on Sprint (¬£17.5k): 1.7 months

2) Base
- 20 hrs saved/month; ¬£45/hr => ¬£900/month/person ‚Üí 30 people = ¬£27,000/month (¬£324k/year)
- Payback: 0.65 months

3) Aggressive
- 30 hrs saved/month; ¬£60/hr => ¬£1,800/month/person ‚Üí 30 people = ¬£54,000/month (¬£648k/year)
- Payback: 0.32 months

Value metrics to track: hours saved per role, % of team weekly AI use, time‚Äëto‚Äëfirst‚Äëimpact, cost per hour saved.

Revenue Expansion & CLTV
- Upsell opportunities: 1) Managed prompt engineering & tool integrations (¬£3k‚Äì¬£10k/month), 2) Custom LLM fine‚Äëtuning / governance projects (¬£30k+), 3) Subscription access to prompts + analytics (¬£50‚Äì200/user/year), 4) TtT licensing to internal L&D.
- Recurring potential: convert 30‚Äì40% of Sprint clients to support subscription (¬£6‚Äì12k/year avg).
- CLTV example: initial Sprint ¬£17.5k + avg recurring ¬£12k/year over 2 years = ¬£41.5k. Subtract CAC (~¬£6k) ‚Üí net CLTV ‚âà ¬£35.5k.
Actionable insights
- Promote Sprint as primary land-and-expand product; use Exec Briefings as low‚Äëcost lead generator.
- Rapidly productise 40% of content into digital modules to increase capacity 3x and improve margins.
- Package a 12‚Äëmonth subscription (support + analytics + 2 refresher workshops) to turn one‚Äëoffs into predictable ARR.
